questions.text: A 62-year-old female with a history of hypertension and diabetes presents to the emergency department with new-onset chest pain and fatigue. An electrocardiogram shows ST-segment changes suggestive of ischemia. Which scan type should be prioritized in this case?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Thallium scan

 

Explanation:


 

  • This scan specifically evaluates areas of decreased blood flow, making it the most suitable choice given the patient's symptoms and EKG findings suggestive of ischemia.


 

 

Purpose

Scan types

For Myocardial Perfusion

  • Assess ischemia
  • Cold spot: decreased uptake in ischemic areas.
  • Thallium scan (Commonly used)
  • Tetrofosmin
  • Sestamibi scan.

For Myocardial Infarction (Option B ruled out)
  • Assess infarct
  • Hot spot in infarct area as pyrophosphate accumulates and is not metabolized.
  • 99m Tc - Pyrophosphate scan.

For Ventricular Function (Option C ruled out)
  • Evaluate ejection fraction
  • MUGA (Multiple Gated Acquisition) scan (AKA nuclear ventriculography)
    • Radiolabeled RBCs are used
  • Most accurate for ventricular function - Cardiac MRI

 

For Myocardial Viability

(Option D ruled out)
  • Assess the viability of myocardium
  • PETscan - Best investigation for myocardial viability.
    • Perfusion and metabolism mismatch are observed in the PET scan.
    • Perfusion Agents:N-13 ammonia and Rubidium chloride.
    • Metabolism Agent:

FDG-PET is used for glucose metabolism.

  • No FDG uptake indicates a normal heart or an infarct.
  • FDG uptake is present: In the Ischemic Myocardium
 
  • FDG-PET is combined with perfusion imaging for comprehensive assessment.
    • Uptake in PET with low perfusion indicates reversible dysfunction (suggestive of hibernation).
    • Irreversible dysfunction indicates the presence of scar tissue.
  • Note: Hibernating myocardium is ischemic but viable.

questions.text: A 65-year-old man with a suspicion of lung cancer is being evaluated with an FDG PET scan to guide his treatment plan. Which of the following is NOT a typical use of FDG PET in clinical practice?

choices.text: Evaluating the presence of distant metastasis from the primary lung tumor
Differentiating between benign inflammatory conditions and malignant lesions
Staging the extent of lung cancer prior to treatment

questions.solution:
(Option B) Differentiating between benign inflammatory conditions and malignant lesions

 

 

Explanation:

 

Fluorodeoxyglucose (FDG) positron-emission tomography (PET-FDG)

  • Uptake of 18F-FDG (Analogue of endogenous glucose) in large quantities by cancer cells as compared to normal cells

 

Application:

  • Quantification of tumor metabolic activity
  • Diagnosis (lung cancer) and Staging of cancer (Option D ruled out)
  • Assessing distant metastasis (Option A ruled out)
    • More sensitive in primary lung and oesophageal cancer metastatic disease
  • Assessment of response to treatment (Option C ruled out)
    • A decrease in FDG uptake after chemotherapy indicates that the tumor is responding to treatment
  • Routine surveillance following treatment- not commonly preferred.

Not useful in the following situations:

  • High Glycolytic Metabolism tissues: Central nervous system tumors.
  • Inflammation vs. Cancer: Both conditions exhibit increased glucose metabolism. (Option B)
  • Movement disorders
  • Coronary blood flow

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a history of smoking undergoes a positron emission tomography (PET) scan for suspected lung cancer. The scan shows increased radiotracer uptake in the right lung. However, further investigation reveals no malignancy. Which of the following is the most likely cause of this false positive result?

choices.text: Low metabolic activity of the tumor
Physiological uptake due to muscle activity
Inflammation from a recent pneumonia infection

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Inflammation from a recent pneumonia infection

 

Explanation:

Inflammatory conditions, such as pneumonia, can lead to increased uptake of the radiotracer in PET scans, mimicking cancerous activity. This is a common cause of false positive results, where the scan suggests malignancy when there is none.

Challenges in PET Scans

False Positive Results

  • Definition: Indication of cancer activity when there is none.

Common Causes:

Cause

Description

Inflammation and Infection

Conditions like pneumonia, sarcoidosis, and infections (e.g., tuberculosis) cause increased FDG uptake.

Post-Surgical Changes

Inflammatory responses post-surgery may yield false positives if scans are done too soon.

Benign Tumors

High FDG uptake can occur in benign lesions like granulomas or abscesses.

Physiological Uptake

Normal activities (muscle use, brown fat metabolism) may mimic malignancy. (Option B ruled out)

False Negative Results

  • Definition: Failure to detect existing cancer.

Common Causes:

Cause

Description

Low Metabolic Activity Tumors

Cancers like bronchioalveolar carcinoma may show minimal FDG uptake. (Option A ruled out)

Small Tumors

Tumors smaller than detection thresholds may be missed. (Option C ruled out)

Timing of Scans

Timing relative to treatment affects uptake; treated tumors may show reduced FDG levels despite viable cancer.

questions.text: A 55-year-old male is undergoing fractionated radiotherapy for the treatment of a large head and neck tumor. The radiation oncologist opts for a standard fractionation schedule. Which of the following principles is not part of the "5 Rs of Radiobiology" that underlie the rationale for fractionation?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Radioresistance

 

Explanation:

Radioresistance is not one of the "5 Rs of Radiobiology." Instead, radioresistance generally refers to the inherent resistance of certain tumor cells to the effects of radiation, which is not a principle underlying fractionation.

Fractionated Radiotherapy

Definition: Treatment in multiple smaller doses (fractions) to enhance tumor control and protect normal tissue.

Key Principles

  • Therapeutic Window: Balances damage to tumor vs. normal tissue using the "5 Rs of Radiobiology":
    • Radiosensitivity: Tumor cells are more sensitive to radiation. (Option A ruled out)
    • Repair: Normal tissue repairs better between treatments. (Option B ruled out)
    • Reoxygenation: Hypoxic tumor cells reoxygenate, increasing sensitivity. (Option D ruled out)
    • Redistribution: Cells cycle through phases of varying sensitivity.
    • Repopulation: Normal tissue regeneration, affecting treatment outcomes.
  • Fraction Size and Dose: Standard doses are 1.8-2 Gy per session, totaling 50-66 Gy over weeks.

Advances in Fractionation

Technique

Key Features

Spatially Fractionated Radiation Therapy (SFRT)

Delivers heterogeneous doses to spare normal tissue, effective in bulky tumors.

Hyperfractionation

More frequent, smaller doses to enhance local control.

Accelerated Fractionation

Shortens overall treatment time, maintaining or enhancing efficacy.

Challenges

  • Radioresistance: Tumors may develop resistance, requiring careful dose planning.
  • Scheduling: Ideal fractionation depends on tumor type, size, and location; research is ongoing

radiotherapy algorithm" data-author="" data-hash="8211" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/gckvXwSqIcNG5gENcjB11744100465.png" />

fractionation patterns" data-author="" data-hash="8212" data-license="" data-source="" data-tags="April2025" src="https://image.prepladder.com/notes/jBc50eJRLrf7ivoEgqfB1744100485.png" />

questions.text: A 65-year-old patient with a lung tumor is undergoing radiation therapy. The radiation oncologist decides to implement a gating technique to minimize damage to surrounding healthy tissue. What is the primary advantage of using gating for this patient?

choices.text: It shapes the radiation dose to match the tumor's irregular shape.
It prevents the tumor from moving during treatment by immobilizing the patient.
It directs radiation beams from different angles to target the tumor.
Synchronizes radiation delivery with the tumor's position during the respiratory cycle.

questions.solution:
Answer: D) Synchronizes radiation delivery with the tumor's position during the respiratory cycle.

 

Explanation:

 

Gating: (Option B ruled out)

  • It is a technique used to reduce the damage to normal tissues.
  • Monitor and correct organ motion during treatment.
  • It is used for tumors in the lungs, chest, and abdomen, where the tumor can move during treatment due to breathing.
  • The tumor moves with respiration.
  • Radiation is produced only when the tumor is in the line of the beam.
  • If the tumor goes off the beamline, radiation stops. 

3DCRT (3Dimensional Conformal Radiation Therapy):

  • It is a technique used to reduce the damage to normal tissues.
  • CT scans create a 3D image of the tumor, which then directs radiation beams from different angles to target the tumor. (Option C ruled out)

IMRT (Intensity Modulated Radiation Therapy):

  • It is a technique used to reduce the damage to normal tissues.
  • It is better than 3DCRT.
  • Used for tumors with irregular shape.
  • Uses 3D CT images to calculate the radiation dose and shape it to the tumor's 3D shape. (Option A ruled out)
  • Complex patterns of multiple radiation beams from different angles of varying intensity change throughout the treatment to conform to the tumor. (option D ruled out)

questions.text: A 9-year-old patient is undergoing proton therapy for a localized brain tumor located near critical structures like the optic nerve and brainstem. The radiation oncologist uses proton therapy to take advantage of the Bragg peak. What is the primary benefit of using proton therapy with the Bragg peak in this scenario?

choices.text: Uniform radiation delivery to both the tumor and surrounding brain tissues.
Deliver the highest dose of radiation at the tumor site while sparing the optic nerve and brainstem.
Greater radiation scatter, which is ideal for treating tumors near critical structures.
Photon therapy provides better tissue sparing than proton therapy.

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Deliver the highest dose of radiation at the tumor site while sparing the optic nerve and brainstem.

 

Explanation:

  • The Bragg peak is a distinctive property of protons that allows them to deposit most of their energy directly at the tumor site and significantly less radiation to the surrounding critical structures like the optic nerve and brainstem.
  • Protons slow down faster as they travel through tissues and release more energy as they decelerate, culminating in the Bragg peak.

 

Bragg peak:

  • It is a distinct property of protons that describes the point at which a proton beam deposits the maximum amount of energy.
  • Protons, unlike x-rays, slow down faster as they travel through tissues and release more energy as they decelerate, culminating in the Bragg peak.
  • This peak allows the majority of radiation to be focused on the target with minimal scatter to surrounding tissues. (Option A & C ruled out)
  • The proton beam can be shaped to match the tumor, delivering most radiation to the tumor while sparing nearby normal tissues. (Option B)
  • Compared to photon beam therapy (X-ray or gamma ray), proton therapy minimizes radiation scatter. (Option D ruled out)

Dose distributions for a proton (left) and photon (right) craniospinal plan. The proton craniospinal plan considerably spares the normal tissues anterior to the spinal canal and delivers a significantly reduced total integral dose to the patient.

questions.text:
In the image, applicators have been placed on a 58-year-old woman who is undergoing high-dose interstitial brachytherapy for early-stage breast cancer. Which of the following advantages does afterloading provide in this scenario?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Eliminates the need for imaging confirmation before placing the radioactive seeds.
Minimizes radiation exposure to healthcare workers during seed placement.
It enhances the mobility of radioactive seeds for more uniform dose distribution.
Allows for real-time radiation delivery without the use of encapsulated seeds.

questions.solution:
Answer: B) Minimizes radiation exposure to healthcare workers during seed placement.

 

Explanation:

Afterloading techniques involve placing applicators into the tissue before inserting radioactive sources. The radioactive material is then loaded after applicators are correctly positioned, typically using a remote-controlled or computer-assisted system, which helps minimize direct radiation exposure to healthcare workers.

 

Interstitial Brachytherapy:

  • Interstitial brachytherapy is the placement of radioactive sources directly into the tissues.
  • It uses a higher total dose of radiation to treat a smaller area than external beam radiation therapy.
  • Examples: Breast cancer, soft tissue sarcoma.
  • Brachytherapy may be temporary or permanent.
  • Radiation source is encapsulated within a non-radioactive metallic capsule which is referred to as a "seed." This helps prevent the material from moving to other parts of the patient's body. (Options C & D ruled out)
  • Imaging (CT or ultrasound) is used to confirm the accurate placement of applicators before radioactive seeds are inserted. (Option A ruled out)
  • Afterloading: (Option B)
    • After the implant's position is confirmed, the radioactive material is inserted by a process called afterloading.
    • In high-dose brachytherapy, afterloading is done using a computer-controlled machine to reduce manual handling of the radiation.
    • In low-dose brachytherapy, afterloading is done manually by the healthcare worker.

questions.text: Which of the following statements is NOT true regarding the use of linear accelerators (LINAC) in radiotherapy?

choices.text: The X-ray beam used for treatment is generated by an overhead X-ray tube.
LINACs do not require the use of radioisotopes for radiation production.
LINACs are commonly used in brachytherapy procedures.
Microwave energy is used to accelerate electrons within the LINAC.

questions.solution:
Answer: C) LINACs are commonly used in brachytherapy procedures.

 

Explanation:

LINACs are used for external beam radiotherapy, while brachytherapy involves placing radioactive sources directly inside or near the tumor.

 

LINAC (Linear accelerator)

  • In teletherapy (External beam radiotherapy), a cobalt machine and LINAC (linear accelerator) are used. (Option C)
  • LINAC- Linear accelerators do not need a radioisotope. (Option B ruled out)
  • LINACs generate photon x-rays by accelerating electrons to a high speed using microwave energy. Once the X-ray beam is formed, it is shaped and aimed at the target. (Option D ruled out)
  • X-rays generated by LINAC have various energies.

 

LINAC Machine:

  • Overhead X-ray tube emits X-ray beams to the patient. (Option A ruled out)
  • It also has a movable arm that can be mobilized around the patient.
  • The treatment head contains significant shielding material to minimize leakage radiation.

questions.text: External beam radiation therapy is planned for a 58-year-old woman with a diagnosis of superficial basal cell carcinoma on her forehead as she refused surgical intervention Considering the characteristics of various radiation modalities, which type of beam would be the most appropriate for achieving effective treatment while minimizing damage to the underlying tissues?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Electron beams

 

Explanation: Electron beams are ideal for treating superficial skin tumors because they have limited penetration and deposit most of the energy superficially, minimizing damage to underlying healthy tissue. Therefore, it is effective for tumors near the body surface like in this scenario- Skin tumor (basal cell carcinoma).

 

Teletherapy (External beam radiation)

  • It is a form of radiation therapy in which the radiation source is placed at a distance from the body, delivering high-energy radiation beams to treat tumors.
  • External beam sources are:
    • Betatron
    • Cobalt
    • Linear accelerator
    • Neutron beam
    • Photon beam
    • Proton beam
    • Spray radiation
    • Stereotactic radiosurgery such as gamma knife
    • X-ray

 

Types of Beams

Electrons (Option C)
  • Negatively charged particles
  • Limited penetration
  • Effective for tumors near the body surface (Skin tumors)

Photons (Option B ruled out)
  • Can reach deep tumors
  • Scatter radiation along the path
  • Continue through normal tissue after reaching the tumor
  • Made up of high energy:
    • X-rays (LINAC- Linear accelerators) (Option A ruled out)
    • Gamma rays (Option D ruled out)

Protons
  • Positively charged particles
  • No radiation scatter
  • Stop precisely at the tumor location

 

cobalt 60 (Co60)

Linear accelerator
  • The Cobalt machine produces an artificial radioisotope (Co )
  • Advantage: Relative constancy of beam output
  • Source replacement approximately every 4 to 5 years
  • LINAC- Linear accelerators do not need a radioisotope
  • The fast-moving electron beam generates radiation which is used in radiotherapy
  • X-ray beams are produced

 

Advantages of External Beam

  • Painless
  • Do not require a hospital stay in most patients
  • Most patients can continue with their normal daily activities
  • Non-invasive

questions.text: A 65-year-old man has metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC). Which of the following agents would be most suitable for palliative treatment?
questions.solution:
Answer: B) Radium-223

 

Explanation: Radium-223 is useful in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer as it is Chemically similar to calcium.

 

Agents used in radiotherapy:

Agents

Key features

Photon beams
  • External beam radiation therapy
  • Made up of high energy:
    • X-rays (LINAC- Linear accelerators)
    • Gamma rays

Proton beams
  • Positively charged particles
  • Bragg peak

Electron beams

(Option C ruled out)
  • Negative charged particles.
  • Skin tumors located superficially (they can’t travel deeply into tissue)

Radium-223 dichloride (223Ra) (Optin B)
  • Bone metastases in metastatic castration-resistant prostate cancer (mCRPC)
  • Chemical similarity to calcium

Strontium-89 (89Sr)
  • Beta emitter
  • Painful metastatic castrate-resistant prostate cancer

Samarium-153
  • Beta emitters
  • Osseous metastases for primary osteosarcomas
  • Osteosarcoma

Phosphorus-32 (Option A ruled out)
  • Beta emitters
  • Chronic myelogenous leukemia
  • Polycythemia vera
  • Epithelial tumors (ovarian)
  • Craniopharyngioma
  • Primary pericardial tumors- palliative therapy

Iodine 131
  • Beta and gamma emitters
  • Thyroid cancers: Follicular, papillary, and Hürthle cell carcinoma

questions.text: Which of the following best describes the Warburg effect in cancer cells?

choices.text: Cancer cells prefer oxidative phosphorylation under anaerobic conditions
Tumor cells primarily use glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen
Lactate production occurs only under hypoxic conditions in tumors
Mitochondrial function is absent in cancer cells

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Tumor cells primarily use glycolysis even in the presence of oxygen.

 

Explanation:

  • Warburg effect: Cancer cells shift to glycolysis for energy production, even with sufficient oxygen, supporting rapid proliferation.
  • This results in increased glucose uptake and lactate production, a hallmark of many tumors.

 

Warburg Effect

  • Cancer cells prefer glycolysis over oxidative phosphorylation, even in the presence of oxygen.
  • This leads to increased glucose uptake and lactate production, common in many cancers.
  • 18F-fluorodeoxyglucose (18F-FDG), a glucose analog used in PET imaging, helps study this effect.

Mechanisms of 18F-FDG Accumulation

Mechanism

Description

Aerobic Glycolysis

Cancer cells rely heavily on glycolysis, increasing glucose and 18F-FDG uptake, even with oxygen.

Transport & Trapping

GLUT-1 transporters mediate glucose entry. 18F-FDG is phosphorylated and trapped inside cells.

Tumor Heterogeneity

Differences in tumor subtype, size, and microvasculature affect 18F-FDG uptake.

 

Clinical Implications of 18F-FDG

Implication

Details

Prognostic Indicator

Higher 18F-FDG uptake correlates with worse prognosis (e.g., shorter DFS in invasive ductal carcinoma).

Reverse Warburg Effect

Cancer-associated fibroblasts (CAFs) increase glycolysis in tumor cells via metabolic coupling.

Treatment Monitoring

PET imaging tracks changes in 18F-FDG uptake, reflecting therapy responses targeting glycolysis or mitochondria.

 

Cancer cells prefer oxidative phosphorylation under anaerobic conditions (Option A): Oxidative phosphorylation is suppressed, not preferred, in cancer cells.

 

Lactate production occurs only under hypoxic conditions in tumors (Option C): Lactate is produced even in oxygen-rich environments, not just under hypoxia.

 

Mitochondrial function is absent in cancer cells (Option D): Mitochondrial function is reduced but not completely absent.

questions.text: Which liver lesion shows hot spot on the sulphur colloid scan?
questions.solution:
Answer: C) Focal nodular hyperplasia

 

Explanation:

The liver lesion that shows a hot spot on a sulfur colloid scan is: Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH)

Technetium-99m sulfur colloid scan is taken up by Kupffer cells (reticuloendothelial cells) in the liver.
The behavior of lesions on this scan depends on whether they contain functional Kupffer cells:

Lesion

Kupffer Cells

Sulfur Colloid Uptake

Scan Appearance

Focal Nodular Hyperplasia (FNH) (Option C)

Present

Increased uptake

Hot spot

Hepatic hemangioma (Option A)

Absent

No uptake

Cold spot

Hepatocellular carcinoma (HCC) (Option B)

Often reduced/absent

No uptake

Cold spot

Hepatic cyst (Option D)

Absent

No uptake

Cold spot

Sulfur colloid scan

  • It is a nuclear medicine imaging study to assess the liver and spleen.
  • Technetium-99m sulfur-colloid is used.
  • The reticuloendothelial system takes up the sulfur colloid, which includes the Kupffer cells in the liver, spleen, and bone marrow.
  • HCC (Hepatocellular carcinoma) does not have Kupffer cells, it does not show a hot spot on the Sulphur colloid scan. (Option B)

questions.text:
Hepatic hot rim sign is seen in which of the following? 



{{caption_text}}
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) Acute cholecystitis

 

Explanation:

  • The hepatic hot rim sign refers to increased radiotracer uptake in the liver parenchyma adjacent to the gallbladder fossa on a HIDA scan (hepatobiliary scintigraphy).

  • It indicates hyperemia and inflammation of the liver tissue surrounding an inflamed gallbladder.

  • The image shown is a HIDA scan.
  • In acute cholecystitis, the gallbladder fails to fill with the radiotracer due to obstruction of the cystic duct as seen in the image, often caused by a gallstone or edema in the cystic duct.

 

HIDA scan (Hepatobiliary iminodiacetic acid scan)

  • Nuclear imaging test to evaluate the function of the liver, gallbladder, bile ducts, and small intestine.
  • Technetium-99m (99mTc)-labeled derivatives of iminodiacetic acid is used.

Mechanism:

  • Radiotracer follows the bilirubin metabolic pathway (excreted into the bile).
  • This will allow visualization of the biliary tree, gallbladder, and bowel.

 

Application:

Disease/Diagnosis

Findings

Acute cholecystitis (Option B)
  • Non-visualisation of the gallbladder
  • Hot rim sign- inflammation around the gallbladder

Chronic cholecystitis (Option A ruled out)
  • Visualization is reduced or delayed (due to contracted gallbladder)

Gallbladder dyskinesia (Option D ruled out)
  • Low gallbladder ejection fraction

Others

 
  • Bile leaks
  • Biliary obstruction (patency of the intra- and extrahepatic biliary system)
  • Patency of a bilioenteric anastomosis.
  • Biliary atresia

HIDA scan showing non-accumulation of the isotope within the gallbladder. (suggestive of Acute Cholecystitis):

 

Bile leak (Option C):

  • HIDA scan would show radiotracer pooling in areas where bile leakage occurs, which is not consistent with the image shown here.
  • Hence, this option is incorrect.

questions.text:
A 42-year-old woman presents with concerns about a lump on her neck that she first noticed approximately three weeks ago. A scan was performed as shown in the image. Which of the following is incorrect for this scan?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: I-123 is the most commonly used
There is an increased uptake of tracer in one area
99mTc-sestamibi can be used for this scan
Half-life of the most common tracer is 13.2 hours

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: B) There is an increased uptake of tracer in one area

 

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a RAIU scan of the thyroid gland
  • The image shows a cold nodule in which there is a decreased uptake of radioactive iodine in one nodule compared to surrounding tissue.


 

Isotope

Half-Life

Uses

Type of Emission

Iodine-127

Stable

Natural iodine, essential for thyroid function

Not radioactive

Iodine-123

13.2 hours (Option D)

Diagnostic imaging

Gamma rays

Iodine-125

60.14 days

Brachytherapy (permanent implant)

Gamma rays

Iodine-131

8.04 days

Radioablation of thyroid

Beta and gamma rays

 

Thyroid scan

 

Purpose:

  • Diagnostic tool for assessing thyroid function and identifying pathologies.

 

Procedure:

  • Involves administering a radioactive tracer
  • A probe measures the amount of iodine uptake by the thyroid gland.
  • The scan checks for the even distribution of the tracer within the gland.

 

Commonly Used Radioactive Tracers:

  • Iodine Isotopes:
    • I-123: Preferred for less radiation exposure; shorter half-life (Most commonly used) (Option A)
    • I-131: Longer half-life; used less frequently

 

  • 99m-Technetium Pertechnetate: (2nd most commonly used)
    • An analog of iodine; is transported to the thyroid similarly to iodine.
  • Less Common Tracers:
    • 111In-pentoxide
    • Thallium-201 (201Tl)
    • 99mTc-sestamibi (Option C)
    • 99mTc-tetrofosmin

 

 

Condition

Description

Radioactive Iodine Uptake

RAIUS

Normal Nodule
  • Normal appearance of a thyroid nodule on a radioactive thyroid scan.

Normal uptake

Hot Nodule
  • Increased uptake of radioactive iodine in one nodule compared to surrounding tissue.

Increased uptake

Cold Nodule
  • Decreased uptake of radioactive iodine in one nodule compared to surrounding tissue.
  • Increased risk of malignancy

Decreased uptake

Grave's Disease
  • Also known as diffuse toxic goiter
  • Characterized by diffusely increased uptake of iodine.

Diffuse increased uptake

Toxic MNG
  • Presence of both hot and cold nodules
  • Hot nodules appear black and cold nodules appear white.

Mixed uptake

Thyroiditis
  • Inflammation and follicular destruction leading to significantly decreased uptake.

< 5% uptake

Correct Answer: D) Warthin’s tumor

 

Explanation:

  • The image shows a 99m Tc pertechnetate scan showing a focal area of intense abnormal tracer accumulation in the right iliac fossa (arrow)
  • There is gastric mucosa uptake, suggestive of functioning Meckel’s diverticulum.
  • All options mentioned except Warthin’s tumor can show false positive results on a 99m Tc pertechnetate scan

Tc-99m Pertechnetate

 

  • Pertechnetate scan is the diagnostic imaging modality of choice to detect ectopic gastric mucosa (sensitivity 95%).

 

  • False-positive pertechnetate studies may occur in (Option A, B, and C ruled out)
    • Crohn disease
    • Appendicitis
    • Intussusception
    • Abscess
  • Properties
    • Emits gamma radiation for imaging.

 

  • Applications

1. Thyroid imaging:

  • Increased uptake:
    • Graves' disease
    • Hashitoxicosis
  • Normal uptake:
    • Hashimoto disease
  • Decreased uptake:
    • Following I-131 therapy
    • Subacute thyroiditis
    • Excess iodine intake (amiodarone, high iodine diet, iodinated contrast)

 

2. Gastric imaging:

  • Detects ectopic gastric mucosa (e.g., Meckel's diverticulum).
  • Note: Not all cases show positive results.

3. Colon imaging:

  • Visualizes abnormalities related to ectopic gastric mucosa.

4. Bladder imaging:

  • Vesicoureteral reflux (VUR):
    • Detects abnormal urine flow from the bladder to the kidneys.
    • Noninvasive procedure to evaluate urinary tract abnormalities.

5. Salivary gland Imaging:

  • Warthin tumors:
    • Typically, they appear as hot nodules.
    • Important for preoperative diagnosis.
    • Other salivary gland tumors may show cold spots.

questions.text:
Which of the following is incorrect about this scan?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot
Tracer in the bladder is physiological
In cellulitis tracer does not show prolonged retention in delayed phase

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Fibrous cortical defects show hot spot

 

Explanation:

  • The given image is of a Bone scan
  • Fibrous cortical defects show a cold spot

 

Bone scan:

 

Definition

Nuclear medicine study using technetium-99m (Tc-99m-MDP)

Absorption

~50% of injected dose absorbed by bones (2-6 hours post-injection)

Phases of Study

1. Immediate phase

2. Blood pool phase

3. Delayed phase

4. Optional delayed phase

Indications
  • Detection and follow-up of skeletal metastases
  • Radiographically occult fractures (e.g., stress fractures)
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Complex regional pain syndrome
  • Evaluation of hip joint prosthesis for infection or loosening
  • Paget disease

Patient Preparation
  • Optimal hydration
  • Remove metal objects
  • Void before study

Conditions Affecting Uptake
  • Increased uptake in kidneys/liver in conditions like thalassemia and hemochromatosis
  • Poor image quality with reduced renal function

Tracer Dose
  • 740 - 925 Mbq (20 - 25 mCi) administered intravenously in adults

Renal Uptake
  • Useful for detecting renal abnormalities; faint/absent uptake commonly due to renal insufficiency

Results

Normal: If the radiotracer is present evenly throughout all the bones.

Abnormal:

  • Will show hot spots or cold spots as compared to surrounding bone.
  • Hot spots are areas where there is an increased collection of radioactive material.
  • Cold spots are areas that have taken up less of the radioactive material.

Hot Spots

Areas of new bone formation; are seen in:

  • Fractures
  • Osteomyelitis
  • Osteoblastic bone metastasis

Cold Spots

Seen in:

  • Multiple myeloma (normal alkaline phosphatase)
  • Fibrous cortical defects (VS fibrous dysplasia shows hot spots)

Physiological Presence
  • Tracer present in the bladder due to renal excretion (Option B)

Superscan:

  • Multiple bones show hot spots without kidney uptake.
  • Seen in conditions that affect multiple bones, like hyperparathyroidism and renal failure. (Option D)

Triple-Phase Bone Scan:

 

Criteria

Osteomyelitis

Cellulitis

Delayed Phase Imaging

Tracer retained in the bone (hot spot)

The tracer does not show prolonged retention in the bone (Option C)

Blood Pool Imaging

Increased uptake can occur

Increased uptake can also occur

questions.text: A 6-year-old patient is referred for a renal scan to assess for potential scarring or morphological changes in the kidneys due to a history of recurrent urinary tract infections. Which of the following scans would be the most appropriate for evaluating the kidneys in this scenario?
questions.solution:
Correct Answer: C) DMSA Scan

 

Explanation:

  • It is specifically designed to assess renal morphology and can identify structural abnormalities such as scarring, ectopic kidneys, and damage from conditions like vesicoureteral reflux (VUR).
  • It provides a static image of the kidneys, making it particularly useful for evaluating potential damage related to recurrent urinary tract infections.


 

Renal Scan

Purpose

Type

Key Points

DMSA

Assess scar or morphological changes in kidneys (e.g., VUR)

Morphological/Static Scintigraphy
  • Identifies abnormalities (e.g., ectopic kidney)
  • IOC for VUR is VCUG/MCU

DTPA (Option A)

Assess kidney function (GFR)

Dynamic Scintigraphy
  • Estimates GFR
  • Excreted by glomerular filtration, not tubular secretion

MAG3 (Option B)

Evaluate overall renal function

Dynamic Scintigraphy
  • Assesses GFR and tubular function

Diuretic Renography

Assess obstruction in pelvi-ureteric junction

Dynamic Scintigraphy
  • Rule in/out PUJ obstruction in hydronephrosis without hydroureter

Captopril DTPA (Option D)

Evaluate renal artery stenosis and other renovascular diseases.

Dynamic Scintigraphy
  • A significant GFR decrease indicates RAAS dependence
  • Contraindicated in renal artery stenosis

questions.text:
A 45-year-old male presents to the emergency department with a 12-hour history of severe right upper quadrant pain. A scan is performed after the injection of a radiopharmaceutical as shown below. Which of the following findings is not consistent with the image shown?



{{caption_text}}

choices.text: Prompt excretion into the bile ducts
Tracer activity was seen in the gallbladder

questions.solution:
Correct Answer: A) Cystic duct obstruction

 

Explanation:

  • The given image shows a normal Hepatobiliary Iminodiacetic Acid scan (HIDA scan)
  • A normal HIDA scan indicates that there is no obstruction. If the cystic duct were obstructed, the gallbladder would not be visualized.

Scintigraphy principle:

 

1. Radiopharmaceutical Injection

A radioactive tracer (e.g. iminodiacetic acid) is injected through IV. This tracer is taken up by the liver and biliary tract.

2. Gamma Ray Detection

As the tracer moves from the liver to the gallbladder and then to the duodenum, it emits gamma rays, which are detected by a gamma camera.

3. Image Creation

The gamma camera is moved over the abdomen to capture images, allowing visualization of the liver, gallbladder, and biliary tract, revealing their structure and function.

 

Prompt excretion into the bile ducts (Option B): This finding is consistent with a normal scan.

Tracer activity was seen in the gallbladder (Option C): This finding aligns with a normal HIDA scan, where the tracer is taken up by the gallbladder.

Radioisotope used is 99mTc (Option D): This is accurate and consistent, as technetium-99m is the standard radioisotope used in HIDA scans.
